metadata.title: Nano-Graphene induced positive effects on methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion

sections.text:
The effects of nano-graphene on methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion was investigated. Short-term results showed that graphene (30 and 120 mg/L) had significantly positive effects on methane production rate, which increased by 17.0% and 51.4%. Further investigation indicated that acetate-consuming methanogenesis was enhanced. The failure of quinones to replicate graphene stimulation effects on methanogenesis suggested that graphene did not function as electron shuttles. After 55 day’s operation at room temperature (from 20 to 10 ), the methane production rate with 30 mg/L graphene was 14.3% higher than that of the control, while 120 mg/L graphene showed a slight inhibition on methane yield. Illumina sequencing data showed that the archaeal community structure remained fairly constant as the incubated sludge with graphene at low temperature, in which Methanoregula, Methanoseata and Methanospirillum were the dominant species. Besides, Geobacter enrichment was observed with graphene, suggesting that the direct interspecies electron transfer might be promoted.
Key words: anaerobic digestion, methanogenesis, graphene, wastewater treatment, microbial community 1. Introduction
With the expanding industrial development of nano-graphene, it has received
much attention not just due to its unique physical and electrochemical properties (Geim and Novoselov, 2007), but also due to the concerns over its potential ecosystem risks (Hu and Zhou, 2013; Bianco, 2013). The wide applications of graphene in the fields of electrochemistry, photochemotherapy and biochemistry inevitably leads to its releases into the environment, and wastewater treatment plants are expected as one of the ultimate repositories for the waste containing graphene (Ahmed and Rodrigues, 2013). So far, investigation on the antibacterial activity of graphene showed that the attached graphene on bacterial membrane could induce oxidative stress and cell apoptosis (Liu et al., 2011; Santos et al., 2011). These results suggest that microbial activity in engineered systems might be affected by graphene. However, to date, the possible impacts of graphene on microbial process in wastewater treatment plants remain largely unknown.
Recently, anaerobic digestion for wastewater treatment grows at a spectacular
pace, and emerges as a promising solution to energy shortage by converting waste organics to biofuel (mainly in the form of methane) (Lettinga et al., 2011; McCarty et al., 2011). Methanogens play a key role in anaerobic digestion process, however, these microorganisms are sensitive to various factors that might adversely affect their
activities (Chen and Cheng, 2008). Followed by the observation of nanomaterials in wastewater and excess sludge (Brar et al., 2010), numerous researches have been performed to study the effects of nanomaterials, such as metal oxides particles and carbon nanotubes, on microorganisms in wastewater treatment systems (Mu et al., 2011; Zheng et al., 2014; Li et al., 2015b; Qu et al., 2015). Previous publications reported that metal oxide nanoparticles could induce obvious inhibition on methanogenesis caused by their released ions or themselves in anaerobic digestion (Mu and Chen, 2011; Mu et al., 2012; Jiang et al., 2009). However, another recent study revealed that, conversely, positive effects of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on methane yield (Li et al., 2015a). Nevertheless, no significant negative or even positive side effects on anaerobic microorganisms are reported in the presence of carbon nanotubes (Li et al., 2015b; Wang et al., 2014). Thus, it can be learned that nanomaterials exhibited diverse influences on microbial methanogenesis depending on their types and properties. One hypothesis proposed that carbon based materials could function as novel electron shuttles enhancing the conversion of pollutants (Zhang et al., 2014; Pereira et al., 2014; Colunge et al., 2015). Recently, direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) between Geobacter species and Methanosaeta or Methanosarcina species is recognized as an effective form of syntrophy in methanogenic communities (Summer et al., 2010; Rotaru et al., 2014a; Rotaru et al., 2014b). And this process is proven to be promoted with granular activated carbon (Liu et al., 2012a). In addition, in order to resist potential adverse effects caused by nanomaterials, more extracellular
polymeric substances (EPS) will be secreted by microbes to form a protectively dense structure, which is also suggested to be a reasonable explanation for the non-adverse impacts of carbon nanotubes (Li et al., 2015b).
Although the effects of nanomaterials on anaerobic digestion process have been
studied for years, little attention has been paid to the response of anaerobic biomass and microbial process to graphene. Therefore, this study explores the potential influence of graphene on microbial methanogenesis through short- and long-term experiments. Methane production efficiency and general physiological activities of the anaerobic biomass were monitored. Besides, Microbial community analysis and possible mechanism of graphene function were also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Graphene and Sludge
sections.text:
Commercially available graphene was purchased from Nanjing XF NANO
Materials S&T Co. Ltd., China (More details of the graphene information in Supplementary Material). A scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of graphene was obtained using a Hitachi SU8000 (Hitachi High Technologies, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 5.0 kV to visualize their shape (Fig. S1). Stock suspension of graphene was produced by adding 0.1 g of graphene into 0.1 L of distilled water (pH 6.9 ± 0.1) and then sonicated (25 o C, 200 W, 40 kHz) for 1 h for a better dispersion before being diluted to exposure experiments. The original seed sludge, used as the
inoculums of methane production, was collected from the tanks treating residual activated sludge in Dalian, China. The seed sludge was then incubated with synthetic wastewater (Supplementary Material) in an up-flow anaerobic sludge blanket (UASB) reactor (More details regarding the UASB reactor were described in Supplementary Material). 2.2. Short-term Exposure Experiments.
In this work, to conduct the short-term experiments, batch tests were carried out
in 250 mL glass serum reactors with a working volume of 150 mL, each in triplicate. 0.9 g anaerobic sludge (wet weight), withdrawn from the UASB reactor was inoculated in each reactor containing 150 mL synthetic wastewater (Supplementary Material) with a MLVSS concentration of 1200 mg/L. Although the fraction of graphene is thought to be relatively low in sewage treatment plants based on a previous publication that modeled environmental concentrations of engineered nanomaterials (Gottschalk et al., 2009), graphene is likely to accumulate in the activated sludge by forming composites with sludge (Li et al., 2015b). Therefore, according to the publications (Zheng et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2014), 0 (the control), 30 mg/L and 120 mg/L graphene were chosen to investigate the potential impacts on methanogenesis. All reactors were covered with aluminum foil to avoid the possible light-induced effects and after being purged with helium for 10 min to remove oxygen, they were sealed and placed in a water-bath shaker (100 rpm) at 35 ± 1 o C. Glucose was used as carbon source in the batch tests with a concentration of 2000 mg-COD/L
and the test lasted for two weeks. During the research, we monitored the gas compositions to study the effects of graphene on methane production. The accumulative gas in the gaseous phase was described as mmol-gas/g-VSS and the relative methane production (% of the control) was calculated as the comparison between the samples with graphene added and the control during the whole operation period. At the end of each batch test, anaerobic sludge samples were withdrawn from the reactors and rinsed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 0.13M NaCl and 0.01M Na2HPO4 pH 7.2) for further microbial activity assays. 2.3. Long-term Exposure Experiments
Based on the results of short-term tests, long-term exposure experiments were
performed using three identical lab-scale UASB reactors with a working volume of 0.8 L (160 mm height; 80 mm diameter). Each reactor’s setup consisted of a feed vessel, a feeding peristaltic pump, an effluent bottle and a gas collecting device. Each reactor was inoculated anaerobic sludge with a MLVSS of 1200 mg/L. Before being added into the reactors, the microbial culture was evenly mixed with 0, 30 and 120 mg/L graphene through magnetically stirring, at 25℃, for 24 h. After being seeded with the sludge, the reactors were acclimatized for 1 week to form a composite of microorganisms and graphene to reduce the small loss of graphene due to the discharge of effluent. During the long-term period (55 days), all the reactors were fed with the same synthetic wastewater as mentioned above. However, all the reactors were operated in room temperatures (20.0 ± 2.0 to 10.0 ± 2.0 ) and 400 mg-COD/L
glucose was supplied as carbon source to explore the potential stimulation of methanogenesis in the presence of graphene under low organic load and low temperature conditions. The whole experiment was divided into three distinct experimental phases based on different operation temperatures and the hydraulic retention time (HRT) was set as 12 hours during the earlier 13 days and then reduced to 6 hours for the last operation. After the long-term experimental operation, anaerobic sludge samples from each reactor were collected, together with the initial incubated sludge to analyze the microbial community structures. 2.4. Microbial Community Analysis
The microbial community analysis was performed via high-throughput 16S
rRNA gene pyrosequencing according to the method described by Lu et al. (Lu et al., 2012). Briefly, 10 mL of suspended sludge were taken from the bottom of each reactor, and then harvested by centrifugation (11000×g) at 4 for 20 min. The same volume (10 mL) of initial incubated sludge sample was also collected and harvested by the same operation. The genomic DNA was extracted using an extraction kit (Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. V3-V4 region of the archaeal 16S rRNA gene was amplified using the universal primers 349F (5’-GYGCASCAGKCGMGAAW-3’) / 806R (5’-GGACTACVSGGGTATCTAAT-3’). Meanwhile, V3-V4 region of the bacterial 16S rRNA gene was also amplified using the universal primers 341F (5’-CCTACGGGNGGCWGCAG-3’) / 805R (5’-GACTACHVGGGTATCTAATCC-3’). After being purified and quantified,
pyrosequencing was conducted by using Illumina high-throughput sequencing on MiSeq platform. 2.5. Analytical Methods
Gas composition (CH4 and CO2) and volatile fatty acids (VFAs) were measured as
previously described (Qiao et al., 2015). The detailed analytical procedures of extracellular polymeric Substances (EPS), acetate kinase (AK) and coenzyme F420 activities were presented in Supplemental Information. Besides, verification experiments on methane production through microbiological catalysis and the determination of dissolved CH4 in medium and adsorbed CH4 to graphene were also performed, which were described in the Supplemental Information. 2.6. Statistical Analysis
All measurements were performed in triplicate and the results were expressed as
mean ± standard deviation. Statistical analysis was conducted by using one-way ANOVA with the Duncan’s multiple range test (SPSS 19.0) and values of p < 0.05 were considered to be statistically significant.

sections.heading: 3.1. Short-term effects of graphene on methanogenesis
sections.text:
The influence of graphene exposure on methane production was relevant to its
dosage and a significant enhancement in methane yields was observed (Fig. 1A). Compared with the control (0.22 ± 0.01 mmol-CH4/gVSS/d), relative methane
production rate was accelerated by 17.0% with 30 mg/L and further increased to 51.4% higher than that of the control as the dosage of graphene increasing to 120 mg/L (Fig. 1B). It should be noted that the monitored methane yields during the whole experimental operation were the result of biological activity (Fig. S2). Meanwhile, due to the methane solution in the liquid phase and adsorption to the graphene (Fig. S3), the actual methane productions were suggested higher than those described in Fig. 1A (methane composition in the headspace). Apparently, short-term exposure of graphene did not exhibit inhibitory effects on microbial methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion. On the contrary, its presence could accelerate methane production. As mentioned above, some metal oxide nanomaterials were reported to exert suppressing influence on anaerobic digestion process due to the damage to anaerobic microbes caused by their released ions (Mu and Chen, 2011; Mu et al., 2012). However, methane production was not inhibited by graphene, which was similar to a previous observation that a faster methane production rate was induced with 1000 mg/L single-wall carbon nanotubes (Li et al., 2015b).
In consideration of that the glucose could be converted rapidly to smaller organic
compounds (Liu et al., 2012b), thus, VFAs generation on day 2 and day 4 were determined (Fig. 1C and 1D). There were three types of VFAs produced from glucose fermentation on days 2 and 4, propionate, acetate and butyrate, with the last two significantly different from control experiments. On day 2, simultaneous decrease in the acetate and increase in the butyrate production were observed. Similarly, with the
results of methane production that the changes in the acetate and butyrate were also positively associated with the graphene dosages. On day 4, higher concentration of graphene caused a significant decrease in the acetate content, which was 425.4 mg/L (88.9% of the control) with 120 mg/L graphene exposure. In contrary, the concentration of butyrate increased to 203.0 mg/L with 120 mg/L graphene addition (480% of the control). Commonly, acetate was considered as prevailing substrates for acetate-consuming methanogens to produce methane. Considering the sharp increase in methane yield between day 2 and 4 (Fig. 1A), it could be assumed that methanogenesis from acetate was specifically stimulated with graphene. To assess the contribution of acetate-consuming methanogens to methanogenesis, batch tests using acetate sodium as the sole carbon substrate were conducted in the same short-term exposure systems. A similar enhancement in the methane production from acetate was achieved with relative methane production rates enhanced by approximately 10.3% and 25.3% in the presence of 30 and 120 mg/L graphene (Fig. S4). These results indicated that acetate-consuming methanogens had a significant contribution to the methane production and further demonstrated that exposure to graphene could actually induce faster substrates utilization, converting acetate to methane. However, compared with using glucose as carbon source, the increase in the relative methane production from acetate was lower. For instance, the former promotion was 51.4% while the latter was 25.3% with 120 mg/L graphene. Moreover, investigation on H2-consuming methanogenesis with CH3F (3% [v/v], 99%), a selective inhibitor of
acetate-consuming methanogenesis, did not show much difference with that of the control at test graphene concentrations (Fig. S5). Thus, it was suggested that the relative higher methane yield should be stimulated via other pathways rather than H2-consuming methanogenesis. 3.2. EPS Generation and Enzyme Activity
The above results indicated that exposure to graphene could accelerate
methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion. It was well known that the EPS excreted by the microorganisms played an important role in the formation of granular sludge and protection of microorganisms from damage or desiccation (Laspidou and Rittmann, 2002; Xue et al., 2012). In this study, the EPS generation with different dosages of graphene exposure were monitored and compared between treatments. The increase in the graphene dosages resulted in an increase in carbohydrate contents while the amounts of protein showed an obvious decrease trend (Fig. 2A). Accordingly, the ratio of carbohydrate to protein in the total EPS was substantially increased with high exposure of graphene.
The release of biomolecules, such as carbohydrates and protein, from activated
sludge and the ratio of extracted components were usually influenced by different stress conditions. The data pertaining to the creation of EPS in this study was in agreements with previous published works that the ratio of carbohydrate to protein could increase concomitantly when biomass suffered from adverse environmental conditions (Henriques, 2007). More specifically, the carbohydrates were demonstrated
to play an important role in the protection of microorganisms, favoring bio-flocculation and biogranules formation (Liu et al., 2004; Sheng et al., 2005). Therefore, it could be learned that more carbohydrate secreted by microbes might be benefit for forming biogranules to resist potential adverse stress caused by graphene.
Since the methane production was obviously affected by graphene, further
demonstration on the activities of key enzymes, acetate kinase (AK) and coenzyme F420 (F420), responsible for acidogenesis and methanogenesis process, was performed according to a previous publication (Mu and Chen, 2011). Shown in Figure 2B were the relative AK and F420 activities of the anaerobic biomass exposed to graphene, comparing with those of the control. Decreases in the AK activities from 93.7% to 79.4% of the control were observed in the presence of 30 and 120 mg/L graphene. Meanwhile, the coenzyme F420 contents with graphene were notably promoted, which were 1.82 and 2.09 folds than that of the control at graphene concentrations of 30 and 120 mg/L (Fig. 2B), respectively. Besides, the stimulated contents of coenzyme F420 were relevant to the graphene dosages as well. These results were suggested as reasonable explanation for the stimulated methane production in the batch experiments. Although the AK activities decreased with graphene additions, the higher coenzyme F420 contents ensured higher acetate-utilization rates, resulting in a faster conversion of acetate to methane and, consequently, methane production from acetate was enhanced. 3.3. Failure of AQDS to replicate graphene stimulation of methanogenesis
As described in the Introduction, it was assumed that the potential mechanism of
graphene in methane production was attributed to a similar electron shuttles function, which promoted the electron transfer process (Zhang et al., 2014; Pereira et al., 2014; Coluge et al., 2015). Based on this hypothesis, investigation on the potential promotion mechanism was carried out. Recently, extracellular quinones, such as anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonate (AQDS) were widely suggested as efficient electron shuttles between microorganisms and a number of extracellular electron acceptors under anaerobic, including methanogenic conditions (Straub and Schink, 2003; Xu et al., 2013). Thus, additions of AQDS into the same anaerobic digestion system were conducted to investigate the substitution of quinones (AQDS) for graphene.
However, the results showed that AQDS at each concentration gradient studied
did not stimulate methanogenesis compared with that of the control without AQDS (Fig. S6). The failure of quinones (AQDS) to replicate graphene stimulation on methanogenesis process indicated that the presented graphene was not an AQDS equivalent, suggesting that graphene did not function as electron shuttles, at least for methanogenesis process in this study (Liu et al., 2012a). 3.4. Long-term effects of graphene on methanogenesis
The above short-term experiments confirmed that exposed to 30 and 120 mg/L
graphene could significantly promote methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion process. However, it was still unclear whether the presence of graphene will show a different impact during long-term operation. Therefore, continuous experiments should be
conducted to explore the long-term effects of graphene on methane production performance. Low temperature anaerobic digestion (LTAD) for wastewater treatment is considered as an attractive alternative to conventional process. Methanogenic activity enhancement and methanogenic consortia enrichment are two efficient methods to achieve high-rate LTAD (Lettinga et al., 2001; Mckeown et al., 2012). Since enhancement in methanogenesis process was observed under graphene exposure conditions, the other objective of long-term experiment was to investigate whether graphene addition could be used as an available method to enhance LTAD.
Figure 3 illustrated the effects of graphene on variations of gas production,
effluent COD concentrations and pH values in the long-term experiments. It can be seen that during the early 13 days operation with a HRT of 12 h, three reactors showed similar gas generation (Fig. 3A and B). However, differences in methane production were observed when shorten the HRT to 6 h. Although the methane production rates of the three reactors gradually decreased as the temperature dropped from 20 to 10 , 30 mg/L graphene (R2) did cause obviously positive influence on methanogenesis process under each temperature condition, compared with the control reactor (R1). From day 36 to 55, when reactors were operated at 10 ，the methane production rate in the 30 mg/L graphene supplemented reactor (12.8 ± 0.4 mL/gVSS/d), was about 14.3% higher than that in the control reactor (11.2 ± 0.6 mL/gVSS/d). Nevertheless, the methane production rate (8.7 ± 1.2 mL/gVSS/d) was found suppressed with 120 mg/L graphene (R3) as the exposure time increased (Fig.
3A), suggesting that long-term exposure of 120 mg/L graphene caused negative impact on methanogenesis process. Meanwhile, variations of CO2 showed a similar trend as the methane production that a higher CO2 generation was observed with 30 mg/L graphene and a slight inhibition was caused by 120 mg/L graphene (Fig. 3B).
The reduced microbial activity of all reactors in response to the temperature
shock was exemplified by reduced COD removal efficiency and pH values (Fig. 3C and D). However, in contrast to gas production of these reactors, graphene exposure did not result in strong variations of effluent COD concentrations and pH values among these reactors. For instance, the average COD removal efficiency of R2 decreased from 87.5% to 50% as the temperature dropped from 20 to 10 , which did not show much difference with that of R1. Besides, the pH values of each reactor showed a similar reducing trend during each distinct. These data suggested that the variations of gas productions among the investigated reactors were significantly different. When exposed to 30 mg/L graphene, methanogenesis process was promoted during the whole operation period, which was consistent with the short-term experiments. However, as the dosages of graphene increased to 120 mg/L, adverse impacts on methane production was observed. 3.5. Microbial Community Compositions
After 55 days, archaeal and bacterial communities in the bulk sludge of each
reactor and the initial incubated sludge were analyzed via high-throughput 16S rRNA pyrosequencing. The majority of sequences affiliated with 8 archaeal genera and 26
bacterial genera were shown in Figure 4. The dominant bacterial genera (relative abundance > 5%) in the microbial communities and their reported metabolism were shown in Table S2.
In the incubated sludge Methanoregula (66.70%), Methanosaeta (18.72%) and
Methanospirillum (9.67%) were the dominant sequences (Fig. 4A). In R1, as temperature gradually decreased, large amounts of H2-consuming methanogens, Methanobacterium (31.39%) were observed while the Methanosaeta sequences decreased to 2.25% (Fig. 4A). Psychrophilic H2-consuming methanogens emerged as important members at low temperature cultivation and this study was consistent with previous reports, in which Methanoseata-like (acetate-consuming) methanogens decreased while H2-consuming methanogens dominated (Mckeown et al., 2009; Kim et al., 2013). Besides, an obvious enrichment of genus Methanosarcina (4.29%) known as the most metabolically diverse methanogens (Galagan et al., 2002) was also detected in R1, indicating potential methane producing pathway changes in R1. However, in the presence of graphene, the archaeal community structure in both R2 and R3 remained fairly constant as the incubated sludge under low temperature conditions (Fig. 4A). It was assumed that the dense structure formed by the bound EPS and graphene mentioned above could create as a protective barrier for the microbes to resist the temperature changes and retain stable methane yield.
In all of the reactors the dominant bacterial sequences were closely related to
microorganisms known to metabolize glucose to short-chain fatty acids. In the
incubated sludge the dominant members of bacterial community were most related to Barnesiella (54.96%), Lactococcus (11.00%) and Allobaculum (7.01%) (Fig. 4B). The most abundant genus Barnesiella was found to belong to the Porphyromonadaceae family, which was reported to degrade glucose into a significant amount of butyrate, isobutyrate and acetate (Sakamoto et al., 2007; Zhao et al., 2013). The bacterial community structure significantly shifted under low temperature operation conditions. In R1, Caldisericum (30.00%) became the most abundant genus and the genus Olsenella (13.37%) replaced Lactocossus as the primary lactate producer, suggesting that they were more adaptive to low temperature. However, in the presence of graphene the bacterial community compositions showed apparent differences comparing with that of R1. Anaerolinea (24.26% of R2 and 16.90% of R3), known as ‘semi-syntrophic’ bacteria had been found dominant in mesophilic anaerobic digesters degrading short-chain fatty acids (Jin et al., 2016; Yuan et al., 2016), but the observation of this study was contrary to the conventional understanding. Besides, Lactocossus still function as the primary lactate producer in R2 and R3. This phenomenon was similar with the development of archaeal community in the presence of graphene, which further revealed the early assumption mentioned above. Several other dominant bacteria genera (relative abundance > 5%) were also detected in R2 and R3, such as Desulfovibrio, Sunxiuqina, Pseudomonas and Sedimentibacter. Their possible roles were to participate in hydrolysis, acidogenesis or acetogenesis with the production of H2. Furthermore, comparing the microorganisms’ communities
between R2 and R3, the reduced abundance of dominant species, such as Methanoseata, Lactococcus and Anaerolinea suggesting that long-term exposure of 120 mg/L graphene might suppressed their growth and affect the methanogenesis performance afterwards.
Besides, it should be noted that the genus of Geobacter was found enriched in
R2 (1.35%) and R3 (1.64%) compared with that of R1 (0.15%). Considering that the Methanoseata species comprised a large percentage of the methanogen community in the test system, DIET process might be promoted when graphene played as electric connections between Methanoseata and Geobacter (Zhao et al., 2016). Thus, Methanoseata species could consume electrons derived from the oxidation of propionate or butyrate to acetate. This would be expected as one reasonable explanation for the existence of Methanoseata as dominant methanogens, while H2-consuming methanogens, Methanobacterium was not enriched at low temperature as we observed.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
This investigation showed a clear positive effects of graphene on methanogenesis
in anaerobic digestion through both short- and long-term experiments. Acetate-consuming rather than H2-consuming was enhanced in the presence of graphene. During the long-term operation under low-temperature conditions, the archaeal community structure in the reactors with graphene added could remain constant as the incubated sludge while the bacterial community structure shifted
significantly. It is believed that this research may open a door for the utilization of graphene as efficiently conductive media or carriers for microbes to promote anaerobic digestion performance.

So far, investigation on the antibacterial activity of graphene showed that the attached graphene on bacterial membrane could induce oxidative stress and cell apoptosis (Liu et al., 2011; Santos et al., 2011).

Recently, anaerobic digestion for wastewater treatment grows at a spectacular pace, and emerges as a promising solution to energy shortage by converting waste organics to biofuel (mainly in the form of methane) (Lettinga et al., 2011; McCarty et al., 2011).

Methanoseata species comprised a large percentage of the methanogen community in the test system, DIET process might be promoted when graphene played as electric connections between Methanoseata and Geobacter (Zhao et al., 2016).

metadata.abstractText: The effects of nano-graphene on methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion was investigated. Short-term results showed that graphene (30 and 120 mg/L) had significantly positive effects on methane production rate, which increased by 17.0% and 51.4%. Further investigation indicated that acetate-consuming methanogenesis was enhanced. The failure of quinones to replicate graphene stimulation effects on methanogenesis suggested that graphene did not function as electron shuttles. After 55 day’s operation at room temperature (from 20 to 10 ), the methane production rate with 30 mg/L graphene was 14.3% higher than that of the control, while 120 mg/L graphene showed a slight inhibition on methane yield. Illumina sequencing data showed that the archaeal community structure remained fairly constant as the incubated sludge with graphene at low temperature, in which Methanoregula, Methanoseata and Methanospirillum were the dominant species. Besides, Geobacter enrichment was observed with graphene, suggesting that the direct interspecies electron transfer might be promoted.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
